entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin officium service, duty, office, from opus work + facere to make, do operate, do

def.dt: :a special duty, charge, or position conferred by an exercise of governmental authority and for a public purpose :a position of authority to exercise a public function and to receive whatever emoluments may belong to it
:a position of responsibility or some degree of executive authority
def.set: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin officium, from Latin
def.dt: :a prescribed form or service of worship
:divine office
:a religious or social ceremonial observance :rite
:something that one ought to do or must do :an assigned or assumed duty, task, or role
:the proper or customary action of something :function
:something done for another :service
:a place where a particular kind of business is transacted or a service is supplied: as
:a place in which the functions of a public officer are performed
:the directing headquarters of an enterprise or organization
:the place in which a professional person conducts business
:the apartments, attached buildings, or outhouses in which the activities attached to the service of a house are carried on
:a major administrative unit in some governments British Foreign Office
:a subdivision of some government departments Patent Office
:a boy or man employed for odd jobs in a business office
:of or relating to the inner workings of a business or institution :internal back–office operations
:a ticket office
:one in a railroad station
:an office (as in a theater) where tickets of admission are sold
:income from ticket sales (as for a film)
:the ability (as of a show) to attract ticket buyers
:something that enhances that ability any publicity is good box office
:the office for the canonical hours of prayer that priests and religious say daily
:a government office (as a ministry) that deals with foreign affairs
:the policy-making officials of an organization usually hyphenated when used attributively the front-office staff

dt.un: used formerly as the name of the Roman Catholic congregation of the curia charged with protecting faith and morals that is now called the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith

def.dt: :a government office in which entries upon and sales of public land are registered
